slides.content: Must-know polyatomic ions: nitrate NO3-, nitrite NO2-, sulfate SO4^2-, sulfite SO3^2-, phosphate PO4^3-, carbonate CO3^2-.
Also memorize: ammonium NH4+, hydroxide OH-, acetate C2H3O2- (or CH3COO-), perchlorate ClO4-, chlorate ClO3-, hypochlorite ClO-.
Tip: oxyanion families share charges across -ate/-ite pairs (e.g., SO4^2- & SO3^2-).

slides.content: -ate = common form with more oxygens (e.g., sulfate SO4^2-). -ite = one fewer O (sulfite SO3^2-).
per- = one more O than -ate (perchlorate ClO4-). hypo- = one less O than -ite (hypochlorite ClO-).
Charge usually stays the same across an oxyanion pair (e.g., SO4^2- & SO3^2-).

slides.content: Common charges: nitrate NO3- (-1), sulfate SO4^2- (-2), phosphate PO4^3- (-3).
Positive polyatomic: ammonium NH4+ (+1). Use to form salts like NH4Cl.
When combining ions, charges must cancel (e.g., Ca2+ + 2 NO3- -> Ca(NO3)2).

slides.content: Br√∏nsted-Lowry: acid = proton (H+) donor; base = proton acceptor.
Example: HCl + H2O -> H3O+ + Cl- (HCl donates H+, water accepts).
This definition works beyond aqueous solutions (broader than Arrhenius).

posts.title: Strong vs weak acids/bases quick guide
posts.author: aq_reactions

comments.author: shortcut_sam
comments.content: Strong acids = complete ionization. Strong bases = strong hydroxides. simple.

comments.author: hf_sufferer
comments.content: HF is weak even though it's scary. weird chem flex.

comments.author: ionmemorize
comments.content: Group 1 OH- are instant strong bases. write that down.

slides.content: Strong acids: HCl, HBr, HI, HNO3, H2SO4 (first H strong), HClO4. They ionize fully in water.
Weak acids/bases: partially ionize (e.g., CH3COOH, HF, NH3). Their equilibrium matters (Ka, Kb).
pH depends on concentration + strength. 0.1 M strong acid is lower pH than 0.1 M weak acid.

comments.author: salty_sue
comments.content: Neutralization = party where acid + base cancel out and salt is leftover üßÇ

comments.author: carbonate_cat
comments.content: If carbonate present you also get CO2 gas. confused me on a quiz once smh

comments.author: labrat_lee
comments.content: Titration endpoint ‚â† equivalence point sometimes. phenolphthalein flexes.

slides.content: Neutralization: acid + base -> salt + water. Example: HCl + NaOH -> NaCl + H2O.
Salts come from the cation of the base and the anion of the acid (Na+ + Cl- -> NaCl).
Special case: acid + carbonate -> CO2 gas + water + salt (e.g., HCl + Na2CO3 -> NaCl + H2O + CO2).

comments.author: bbq_ben
comments.content: This explains my grill chemistry. too hot to handle üî•

comments.author: chem_teacher
comments.content: Remember: products are CO2 + H2O when O2 is sufficient.

comments.author: safety_mom

slides.content: Complete combustion: hydrocarbon + O2 -> CO2 + H2O (e.g., CH4 + 2 O2 -> CO2 + 2 H2O).
Balance C first, then H, then O. If O2 fraction appears, multiply to clear fractions.
Sufficient oxygen = complete (clean) combustion producing CO2 and H2O.

comments.author: soot_bae
comments.content: Black smoke = incomplete burn. learned that after a candle experiment üò¨

comments.author: co_alert
comments.content: Carbon monoxide forms in poor ventilation. deadly, pls be careful.

comments.author: chem_explain
comments.content: CO forms when C partially oxidized; soot = elemental carbon left behind.

slides.content: Incomplete combustion happens with limited O2 ‚Äî products can include CO, C (soot), and less CO2.
CO is toxic and odorless. Soot is particulate carbon ‚Äî both are bad news.
Improve airflow/oxygen to favor complete combustion and avoid CO/soot.

comments.author: fraction_fred
comments.content: Fraction method saved my exam. put 7/2 then multiply by 2, ez.

comments.author: panic_pat
comments.content: Still panic if carbons odd ngl. but this helps.

comments.author: quicktip
comments.content: Balance C then H then O. it's practically a law of nature here.

slides.content: Step 1: Balance carbons (CO2 count). Step 2: Balance hydrogens (H2O count). Step 3: Count oxygens and solve for O2.
If O2 coefficient becomes fractional, multiply whole equation to clear fractions.
Example: C3H8 + (5/2)O2 -> 3CO2 + 4H2O. Multiply by 2 -> 2C3H8 + 5O2 -> 6CO2 + 8H2O.
